I've been a long-time fan of Denzel Washington and enjoyed most of his films. The Equalizer (2014) was a great start — dark, balanced, and satisfying. The sequel was weaker, but I still hoped the third one would bring the franchise to a proper close. Sadly, I have mixed feelings.

Robert McCall is a fascinating vigilante — a man seeking redemption through justice. That theme returns strongly here, and it’s where the film truly shines. The slower rhythm, the introspective tone, and the stunning cinematography of southern Italy give the movie a beautiful, almost poetic touch. The small-town interactions and McCall’s conversations with Emma (Dakota Fanning) are among the highlights.

Unfortunately, the story itself feels hollow. The plot seems like an afterthought — as if someone added random violence to justify calling it an Equalizer movie. The mafia subplot lacks depth and tension; there’s no real sense of danger or challenge. Even McCall’s signature brutality feels off — still gruesome, but stripped of meaning. When he tells a villain, “You have six minutes left to live,” it’s supposed to sound menacing, but instead feels forced and cliché.

In the end, Equalizer 3 is visually stunning but emotionally empty. It feels less like a thrilling conclusion and more like a quiet farewell that doesn’t know what to say.

Chemistry on screen draws you in when it hits, the choices characters make between each other in those moments we often fondly resonate with after; even months after watching. 

Here Denzel and Dakota pick up like decades have not gone by between where they are now, and when they first gave us  a brilliant performance in Man On Fire. The beautiful Italian back drop give this film a grounded appreciation which grows on you; it doesn’t need the large budget explosions. 

I’m very much looking forward, excited to hear Denzel & Fuqua signed on for 2 more sequels. More Dakota and Denzel has proven to be a collaboration that doesn't miss, and we're here for it.
